questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening pain in his left heel over the past 3 months. He says that the pain is worse in the morning when he gets up from the bed but decreases as he starts walking. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with prediabetes. He started jogging daily and working out in an attempt to lose weight. He does not take any medications. He drinks 3–4 beers on weekends but does not smoke or use illicit drugs. He is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness over the medial aspect of the left heel's inferior surface and worsening of the pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes. The pain is not reproduced upon squeezing the sides of the heel. An x-ray of the foot shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Recurrent microtrauma to the Achilles tendon
Impingement of the S1 nerve root

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recurrent microtrauma to the Achilles tendon leads to Achilles tendinopathy, which manifests with heel pain. This condition commonly affects runners and individuals who, like this patient, suddenly increase the intensity of their training. However, patients with Achilles tendinopathy present with pain in the posterior heel (proximal to the insertion of the Achilles tendon) rather than with pain on the inferior surface of the heel.

B) INCORRECT:

Impingement of the S1 nerve root can cause pain in the S1 dermatome, which includes the heel. However, pain in this condition typically radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg into the sole. Furthermore, characteristic findings of S1 radiculopathy include a weakened plantar flexion, a decreased ankle reflex, a positive straight leg raise test, and sensation deficits in the S1 dermatome, none of which is seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with progressive heel pain suggestive of plantar fasciitis, a condition thought to be caused by degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis. Heel pain in plantar fasciitis is typically located on the inferior heel over the medial calcaneal tuberosity (the site of insertion of the plantar aponeurosis) and can be elicited by stretching the aponeurosis through passive dorsiflexion of the toes and simultaneous palpation along the plantar fascia. The pain is usually worse in the morning, gradually lessens with activity, and increases again towards the end of the day after long periods of weight-bearing. Obesity and overtraining (e.g., running) are risk factors associated with this condition. An x-ray of the foot is often normal; however, in some patients, a concurrent calcaneal heel spur is visible. Imaging is not necessary to establish the diagnosis but can help rule out differentials (e.g., fractures).

The initial treatment is conservative and includes rest, ice massage, a 2–3 week trial with NSAIDs, avoidance of flat shoes and barefoot walking, and stretching and strengthening exercises. Patients who do not improve under conservative therapy can be treated with locally injected glucocorticoids.
Image Description:

X-ray (lateral view)

A bony outgrowth (green overlay) projects from the calcaneal tuberosity at the origin of the plantar fascia.

C: calcaneus

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa is seen in retrocalcaneal bursitis, which manifests with heel pain. This condition can affect runners and individuals who, like this patient, suddenly increase the intensity of their training or overtrain. However, patients with retrocalcaneal bursitis present with pain in the posterior heel and ankle rather than on the inferior surface of the heel.

E) INCORRECT:

Impingement of the tibial nerve causes tarsal tunnel syndrome (TTS), which can manifest with heel pain. TTS is most often part of the sequelae of traumatic ankle injuries but may also be the result of repetitive stress and improper running techniques (overpronation). However, unlike this patient's findings, pain in TTS usually worsens with activity and is typically accompanied by paresthesias. Focal tenderness on palpation would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

A stress fracture of the calcaneus manifests with heel pain that commonly begins in the morning upon weight bearing. This condition can be seen in individuals who are involved in activities that cause repetitive microtrauma in the foot, similar to this patient's intensive, daily running program. Because stress fractures are not always visible on radiography, an x-ray of the foot may be normal. This patient's pain decreases with physical activity whereas the pain in calcaneus stress fractures persists or increases with walking. There would also be tenderness over the medial and lateral aspects of the posterior heels, rather than the inferior surface. Finally, pain from a calcaneus stress fracture is characteristically elicited by squeezing the sides of the heel.
questions.hint: This condition is the most common cause of heel pain.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old female ballet dancer reports a 3-week history of a sharp pain on the inside part of the arch towards her left heel. The pain is severe when she starts to walk after periods of rest and is limiting her ability to dance. It is worse in the morning but generally improves with rest or if she walks on the lateral aspect of her foot. Acetaminophen does not provide adequate relief. She has no history of trauma or recent illness.
On physical examination, there is no evidence of synovitis. Left-heel pain is reproduced when the left great toe is passively dorsiflexed or the soft tissue of the sole is palpated from the heel to the forefoot. Tenderness is most pronounced at the front of the inferior aspect of the heel. Tinel sign is negative. There is no pes planus or tenderness of the Achilles tendon.
Plain radiography of the left foot reveals soft-tissue swelling around a spur at the inferior aspect of the calcaneus.
What is the best next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein level
Glucocorticoid injection into the site of greatest pain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immobilization with a cast would be appropriate for a stress fracture but not as first-line therapy for plantar fasciitis. Braces that are worn at night to keep the ankle in dorsiflexion are a consideration for refractory cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing of inflammatory markers, such as the erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels, are not helpful in diagnosing plantar fasciitis. These levels will be normal unless there is coexistent inflammatory disease or an underlying infection such as osteomyelitis of the calcaneus, neither of which is likely in this patient given the history and examination.

C) CORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis is the most common cause of inferior heel pain in adults, with a peak incidence from age 40 to 60 years in the general population and at younger ages in athletes such as runners or ballet dancers. The cause is most likely multifactorial, with risk factors including obesity, prolonged standing or walking, reduced ankle dorsiflexion, pes planus (flat feet), and injury from repetitive microtrauma (e.g., from athletic activities on hard surfaces).

The predominant symptom of plantar fasciitis is pain in the plantar region of the foot while bearing weight. This pain is worst after a period of rest, typically within the first few minutes after initiation of walking. The pain may improve over the course of the day and is diminished if the patient walks on the front or the lateral aspect of the foot.

A hallmark for the diagnosis of plantar fasciitis is local tenderness in the distal aspect of the heel-pad, overlying the medial calcaneal tubercle. Heel pain may also be reproduced when the plantar fascia is pulled taut by dorsiflexion of the great toe and the fascia is simultaneously palpated from the heel to the forefoot. Examination should also include evaluation for a tight gastrocnemius muscle or pes planus. Posterior heel pain is not part of the presentation of plantar fasciitis and, if present, would suggest other diagnoses. A positive Tinel sign (i.e., pain or paresthesia caused by tapping over the tibial nerve on the medial aspect of the ankle) is more common in tarsal tunnel syndrome, which can mimic plantar fasciitis.

The evidence for effectiveness of commonly used therapies is limited. Therefore, initial therapy with conservative measures such as rest, icing, and exercises that stretch the plantar fascia (ankle dorsiflexion, toe dorsiflexion) are recommended. A short course of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs is also reasonable. Changes to footwear (e.g., heel cups or medial arch supports) may provide relief.

Key learning point: The site of greatest tenderness in a patient with plantar fasciitis is the heel.

D) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoid injection may lead to more rapid relief of pain, its use in plantar fasciitis is controversial given concern about rupture of the aponeurosis and atrophy of the heel fat pad.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies (including MRI) can be helpful in ruling out other disorders, such as calcaneal stress fractures, in cases in which the diagnosis is unclear. MRI would show increased thickness of the plantar, fat-pad abnormalities, or both, but such imaging is not necessary to diagnose plantar fasciitis.

X-ray (lateral view)

A bony outgrowth (green overlay) projects from the calcaneal tuberosity at the origin of the plantar fascia.

Inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa is seen in retrocalcaneal bursitis, which manifests with heel pain. This condition can be seen in individuals who are involved in activities that cause repetitive microtrauma in the foot, similar to this patient's intensive, daily running program. Finally, pain from a calcaneus stress fracture is characteristically elicited by squeezing the sides of the heel.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old recreational runner presents with four months of progressively worsening sharp foot pain along the underside of her left foot. The pain is sharp with the first few steps in the morning, temporarily eases after mild activity, and returns after prolonged standing. Examination shows focal tenderness near the medial calcaneal region, without visible swelling or deformity (see report).
Radiographic studies: Unremarkable
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achilles tendinopathy typically presents with tenderness along the Achilles tendon on the posterior heel, not the medial calcaneal region. Pain is often exacerbated by activities involving forceful plantar flexion. The absence of palpable swelling or deformity in the posterior heel and unremarkable radiographic findings argue against this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Morton neuroma usually presents with neuropathic pain localized to the interdigital space, typically between the third and fourth metatarsal heads. The pain is often burning or shooting, with a palpable mass or positive Mulder's sign. The described pain pattern and location are inconsistent with Morton's neuroma.

C) INCORRECT:

Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the tibial nerve, presenting with burning pain, tingling, and numbness along the plantar surface. The absence of neuropathic symptoms and a positive Tinel’s sign, along with normal radiographic findings, diminishes the likelihood of this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis manifests with pain on the plantar aspect of the heel, often at the medial calcaneal tuberosity where the plantar fascia originates. Patients typically report sharp pain with the first steps in the morning due to decreased tissue elasticity after rest, which temporarily improves with activity as the fascia warms up. Pain recurs after prolonged standing due to repetitive microtrauma and overuse, leading to degeneration at the fascia’s attachment. Radiographic studies are usually unremarkable, though calcaneal spurs may occasionally be present. The clinical presentation, pain patterns, and pathophysiology align with plantar fasciitis.

Key learning point: Plantar fasciitis is characterized by pain and tenderness on the midline plantar surface of the foot, often exacerbated by standing and walking, and is common in athletes.
Image Description:

In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).
